A glossary of Cockney slang is being prepared for Americans so they will be able to understand ''EastEnders,'' the most popular TV show in British history, when it airs in the United States next year. A1

A new South Korean constitution that clears the way for the country's first direct presidential elections in 16 years, was endorsed in the first popular test of South Korea's sweeping democratic changes. A1

News analysis: Peace in Sri Lanka, to many analysts, appears more distant than ever, although by capturing the Tamil rebel stronghold of Jaffna this week, Indian Army troops signaled their determination to enforce a peace accord in the troubled island nation. A10

As deficit-reduction talks began, several key leaders sought to dampen expectations that the negotiations could produce savings larger than $23 billion this year. Eager not to disappoint financial markets, many negotiators are suggesting a multiyear reduction package instead. A1
Economic analysis: Shrinking the Federal budget deficit by raising taxes and cutting Government spending would be the wrong thing to do at the worst possible time, some economists say. A1

A measure of stability returned to Wall Street as investors, heartened by stock rallies abroad, drove prices higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 52.56 points, or 2.9 percent, to close at 1,846.49. A1

News analysis: President Reagan is perplexed by calls for greater leadership from the White House, his aides say, as the stock market continues its gyrations and Americans worry that the nation is at the edge of an economic precipice. D13
The staggering of the stock market has not scarred the public psyche, the Republican Party or the President as much as some at first predicted, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. D14

A bill that provides protection against the costs of catastrophic illnesses for more than 31 million elderly and disabled people was passed by the Senate, 86 to 11, after adding a new benefit to pay for prescription drugs. A1

Evidence of an AIDS death in 1969 in St. Louis suggests that the virus may have been introduced into the United States several times before touching off the current epidemic, according to experts in disease transmission.

The White House chief of staff met with two key Senate Democrats to seek their views on about 13 Federal judges being considered for the next nomination to the Supreme Court. It is not clear when President Reagan will make the nomination. B10

The Navajo Nation will build a resort on its reservation in a joint venture with the designer Oleg Cassini, Peter MacDonald, the tribal chairman, announced, as Federal officials grappled with how to give tribes more control over their destiny. A20

Mayor Koch announced big cutbacks in municipal hiring, suspension of salary increases and withdrawal of added pension contributions, including a 90-day freeze on 5,200 jobs, brought about by concern over the plunge of the stock market and fears of a recession. B1

A plan to find jobs for students who graduate from New York City high schools by creating ''employment offices'' staffed with business people in the schools has been devised by the chairman of the Primerica Corporation. B1

A detective took unorthodox steps during the police inquiry into the beating of Governor Cuomo's father-in-law three years ago that may have hampered the search for evidence, a review of police records and interviews show. B3

A new, weighted voting formula for New York City's Board of Estimate was proposed by the City Council President in an effort to preserve the board. The proposal was denounced by other board members, who said it was unfairly weighted. B3
